How to Boost Cursor‚Äôs Understanding of Your Entire Codebase
I‚Äôve been using Cursor for months now, and while it‚Äôs great at understanding individual files, I always felt frustrated when working with larger codebases.
Cursor would give me solid suggestions for the code I was looking at, but it struggled to understand how everything connected across my project.
The Problem I Was Facing
Working on a React/Node.js project with about 200 files, I‚Äôd constantly run into situations where:
- I wanted to refactor a function but couldn‚Äôt easily see what would break
- I needed to understand data flow across multiple components
- I was looking for similar patterns that already existed in the codebase
- Onboarding new team members was painful because they couldn‚Äôt grasp the overall architecture
Cursor helped with individual files, but I was missing the bigger picture.
That‚Äôs when I decided to use Deep Graph MCP to enhance Cursor‚Äôs repository knowledge and give it the architectural context it was missing.
What Deep Graph MCP Actually Does
Instead of Cursor only seeing your current file, Deep Graph MCP gives it a map of your entire codebase as an interconnected graph. Now I can ask questions like:
- ‚ÄúWhat functions call this authentication method?‚Äù
- ‚ÄúShow me the complete data flow from this API endpoint‚Äù
- ‚ÄúFind similar error handling patterns in this codebase‚Äù
And get accurate, contextual answers.
How I Set It Up
The setup took me about 5 minutes:
Step 1: Open Cursor Settings
Cursor > Settings
- Go to ‚ÄúTools & Integrations‚Äù ‚Üí ‚ÄúMCP Tools‚Äù
- Click on ‚ÄúAdd Custo MCP‚Äù
Step 2: Add This Configuration
For public repos like facebook/react (if you want test first):
{
"mcpServers": {
"Deep Graph MCP": {
"command": "npx",
"args": [
"-y",
"mcp-code-graph@latest",
"facebook/react"
]
}
}
}
For my private project (needed a CodeGPT account):
{
"mcpServers": {
"Deep Graph MCP": {
"command": "npx",
"args": [
"-y",
"mcp-code-graph@latest",
"YOUR_CODEGPT_API_KEY",
"CODEGPT_API_KEY", // Required
"CODEGPT_ORG_ID", // Optional
"CODEGPT_GRAPH_ID" // Optional
]
}
}
}
Create a CodeGPT account for free in this link:
Get your API KEY and ORG ID in the section ‚ÄúAPI Connections‚Äù:
And Upload your repo in Code Graph to get your CODEGPT_GRAPH_ID
With everything set up, you‚Äôll be able to see the MCP and the tools already available.
Use the MCP
To use the MCP you just have to open the cursor chat and it will automatically detect the tools and show you a message to execute them.
Full response directly from the React repository
Real Examples from My Workflow
Here are actual scenarios where this made a difference:
Refactoring a shared utility function: Before: Manually grep through files to find usages Now: ‚ÄúWhat files use the formatDate
function and how?" - instant comprehensive list
Understanding authentication flow: Before: Opening 8 different files to trace the login process Now: ‚ÄúWalk me through the complete user authentication flow‚Äù ‚Äî clear explanation with relevant code snippets
Finding code patterns: Before: Hoping I‚Äôd remember where I implemented similar logic Now: ‚ÄúShow me other places where we handle async API calls with error boundaries‚Äù ‚Äî found 3 similar patterns I‚Äôd forgotten about
What Actually Changed
The biggest change isn‚Äôt the individual features ‚Äî it‚Äôs that Cursor now feels like it actually understands my project. Instead of context-switching between files in my head, I can ask architectural questions and get intelligent answers.
It‚Äôs particularly useful when:
- Planning refactors (understanding impact)
- Code reviews (seeing broader implications)
- Feature development (finding existing patterns)
- Debugging (tracing through call chains)
Small Issues I Hit
Cursor sometimes doesn‚Äôt recognize the MCP for searches. In this case, you have two options:
- Force MCP usage in your prompt: If your MCP is named ‚ÄúDeep Graph MCP‚Äù, add to your prompt: ‚ÄúUse Deep Graph MCP to perform the following task‚Ä¶‚Äù
- Change the MCP name to your repository name: In the JSON configuration, change ‚ÄúDeep Graph MCP‚Äù to your repository name. This way you can ask Cursor more naturally, like: ‚ÄúIn Project A, create the Login component‚Äù
Worth the Setup Time?
Absolutely. It took 5 minutes to set up and has already saved me hours of manually tracing through code. If you work with codebases larger than a few dozen files, this is a no-brainer.
The combination feels natural, Cursor‚Äôs AI capabilities with actual architectural understanding of your project.
Try It Yourself
- Pick a repository (start with a public one to test)
- Add the MCP configuration to Cursor
- Ask it some architectural questions about your code
- See how it changes your workflow
I‚Äôm planning to set this up for our other projects too. It‚Äôs one of those tools that makes you wonder how you worked without it.
Get the tool here: Deep Graph MCP
